text: Who identifies himself at the start of the letter as 'an apostle—not from men nor through man'?
verseText: Paul, an apostle—not from men nor through man, but through Jesus Christ and God the Father, who raised him from the dead—

text: What primary error was troubling the Galatian churches, causing Paul to write this urgent letter?
options: False teachers insisting Gentile believers must follow the Mosaic Law to be saved
verseText: I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting him who called you in the grace of Christ and are turning to a different gospel— not that there is another one, but there are some who trouble you and want to distort the gospel of Christ... Look: I, Paul, say to you that if you accept circumcision, Christ will be of no advantage to you... You are severed from Christ, you who would be justified by the law; you have fallen away from grace.

text: Paul recounts a significant public confrontation in Antioch. Which prominent apostle did he oppose 'to his face' for inconsistent behavior regarding Gentile believers?
verseText: But when Cephas came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face, because he stood condemned... But when I saw that their conduct was not in step with the truth of the gospel, I said to Cephas before them all, “If you, though a Jew, live like a Gentile and not like a Jew, how can you force the Gentiles to live like Jews?”

text: A famous verse declares the equality of believers in Christ, stating 'There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is no...' what third pair?
verseText: There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is no male and female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus.

text: What is the central doctrine Paul passionately defends throughout Galatians as the means by which a person is declared righteous before God?
options: Strict adherence to the Mosaic Law
Faith in Jesus Christ apart from works of the Law
verseText: yet we know that a person is not justified by works of the law but through faith in Jesus Christ, so we also have believed in Christ Jesus, in order to be justified by faith in Christ and not by works of the law, because by works of the law no one will be justified.

text: To illustrate the difference between law and promise (slavery and freedom), Paul uses an allegory involving two Old Testament women. Who are they?
verseText: For it is written that Abraham had two sons, one by a slave woman and one by a free woman. But the son of the slave was born according to the flesh, while the son of the free woman was born through promise. Now this may be interpreted allegorically: these women are two covenants. One is from Mount Sinai, bearing children for slavery; she is Hagar... But the Jerusalem above is free, and she is our mother.

text: Before faith in Christ came, what role did the Law serve, according to Paul's analogy?
options: A guardian or tutor to lead us to Christ
A way to earn God's favor
A temporary measure with no real purpose
verseText: So then, the law was our guardian until Christ came, in order that we might be justified by faith.

text: What is the foundational statement about Christian liberty made at the beginning of chapter 5?
options: Freedom means doing whatever you want
For freedom Christ has set us free
Freedom is only for Jewish believers
verseText: For freedom Christ has set us free; stand firm therefore, and do not submit again to a yoke of slavery.

text: In contrast to the 'works of the flesh', what list of qualities does Paul provide as evidence of the Spirit's presence and work?
options: The gifts of the Spirit (tongues, prophecy, etc.)
The fruit of the Spirit (love, joy, peace, etc.)
verseText: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control; against such things there is no law.

text: What agricultural principle does Paul use to illustrate the consequences of one's actions, stating 'God is not mocked'?
options: Whatever one sows, that will he also reap
Rain falls on the just and the unjust
verseText: Do not be deceived: God is not mocked, for whatever one sows, that will he also reap.

text: How does Paul assert the divine origin of his apostleship in the opening verse?
options: Through Jesus Christ and God the Father
verseText: Paul, an apostle—not from men nor through man, but through Jesus Christ and God the Father, who raised him from the dead—

text: What is Paul's tone towards the Galatians at the beginning of the letter?
verseText: I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting him who called you in the grace of Christ and are turning to a different gospel—

text: What does Paul call the teaching that troubled the Galatians?
options: A different gospel, which is no gospel at all
verseText: ...turning to a different gospel— not that there is another one, but there are some who trouble you and want to distort the gospel of Christ.

text: What strong condemnation does Paul pronounce on anyone (even himself or an angel) who preaches a contrary gospel?
verseText: But even if we or an angel from heaven should preach to you a gospel contrary to the one we preached to you, let him be accursed. As we have said before, so now I say again: If anyone is preaching to you a gospel contrary to the one you received, let him be accursed.

text: How did Paul receive the gospel he preached?
options: From the other apostles in Jerusalem
verseText: For I would have you know, brothers, that the gospel that was preached by me is not man's gospel. For I did not receive it from any man, nor was I taught it, but I received it through a revelation of Jesus Christ.

text: What was Paul's background in Judaism before his conversion?
options: He was extremely zealous and persecuted the church
He was unfamiliar with the Law
verseText: For you have heard of my former life in Judaism, how I persecuted the church of God violently and tried to destroy it. And I was advancing in Judaism beyond many of my own age among my people, so extremely zealous was I for the traditions of my fathers.

text: Immediately after God revealed His Son to Paul, where did Paul go?
options: Straight to Jerusalem to consult the apostles
Into Arabia, then returned to Damascus
verseText: ...I did not immediately consult with anyone; nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me, but I went away into Arabia, and returned again to Damascus.

text: How long after his conversion did Paul go up to Jerusalem to visit Peter (Cephas)?
verseText: Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to visit Cephas and remained with him fifteen days.

text: Besides Peter, which other prominent leader did Paul see on that first visit to Jerusalem?
verseText: But I saw none of the other apostles except James the Lord's brother.

text: Fourteen years later, Paul went to Jerusalem again. Who accompanied him?
verseText: Then after fourteen years I went up again to Jerusalem with Barnabas, taking Titus along with me.

text: Why did Paul take Titus, a Greek, to Jerusalem on that visit?
options: As a test case regarding circumcision for Gentiles
verseText: But even Titus, who was with me, was not forced to be circumcised, though he was a Greek.

text: What did the 'pillars' of the Jerusalem church (James, Peter, John) ask Paul and Barnabas to remember?
options: To collect money for the temple
verseText: ...James and Cephas and John, who seemed to be pillars, gave the right hand of fellowship to Barnabas and me... Only, they asked us to remember the poor, the very thing I was eager to do.

text: Why did Paul oppose Peter (Cephas) in Antioch?
options: Peter withdrew from eating with Gentiles due to fear of the circumcision party
Peter wanted to return to Jerusalem
verseText: For before certain men came from James, he was eating with the Gentiles; but when they came he drew back and separated himself, fearing the circumcision party.

text: Paul states that a person is not justified by what?
verseText: yet we know that a person is not justified by works of the law but through faith in Jesus Christ...

text: If justification comes through the Law, what does Paul say about Christ's death?
options: Then Christ died for no purpose
verseText: I do not nullify the grace of God, for if righteousness were through the law, then Christ died for no purpose.

text: How does Paul famously describe his new life in Christ?
options: 'I have been crucified with Christ. It is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me'
'I am free to do as I please'
verseText: I have been crucified with Christ. It is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me. And the life I now live in the flesh I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave himself for me.

text: Paul asks the 'foolish Galatians' if they received the Spirit by works of the law or by what?
verseText: Let me ask you only this: Did you receive the Spirit by works of the law or by hearing with faith?

text: Who does Paul use as the primary Old Testament example of justification by faith?
verseText: just as Abraham “believed God, and it was counted to him as righteousness”?

text: Who are the true sons of Abraham, according to Paul?
options: Those who keep the whole Law
verseText: Know then that it is those of faith who are the sons of Abraham.

text: What does the Law bring to those who rely on 'works of the law'?
verseText: For all who rely on works of the law are under a curse; for it is written, “Cursed be everyone who does not abide by all things written in the Book of the Law, and do them.”

text: How did Christ redeem believers from the curse of the Law?
options: By becoming a curse for us
verseText: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law by becoming a curse for us—for it is written, “Cursed is everyone who is hanged on a tree”—

text: The promise was made to Abraham and to his offspring. Who does Paul identify as the singular 'offspring'?
verseText: Now the promises were made to Abraham and to his offspring. It does not say, “And to offsprings,” referring to many, but referring to one, “And to your offspring,” who is Christ.

text: When was the Law given in relation to the promise made to Abraham?
options: At the same time as the promise
It was part of the original promise
verseText: This is what I mean: the law, which came 430 years afterward, does not annul a covenant previously ratified by God, so as to make the promise void.

text: Why was the Law added, according to Paul?
options: Because of transgressions, until the offspring should come
verseText: Why then the law? It was added because of transgressions, until the offspring should come to whom the promise had been made...

text: Before faith came, how does Paul describe the state of people under the Law?
options: Held captive under the law, imprisoned
verseText: Now before faith came, we were held captive under the law, imprisoned until the coming faith would be revealed.

text: Through faith, what have all believers become?
options: Sons of God, in Christ Jesus
verseText: for in Christ Jesus you are all sons of God, through faith.

text: What happens to those who are baptized into Christ?
options: They become subject to the Law
verseText: For as many of you as were baptized into Christ have put on Christ.

text: If believers belong to Christ, whose offspring are they, and what are they heirs of?
options: Moses' offspring, heirs of the Law
Abraham's offspring, heirs according to promise
David's offspring, heirs of the kingdom
verseText: And if you are Christ's, then you are Abraham's offspring, heirs according to promise.

text: Paul compares an heir who is a child to what?
verseText: I mean that the heir, as long as he is a child, is no different from a slave, though he is the owner of everything,

text: Before Christ, believers were enslaved to what?
options: The elemental principles (or spirits) of the world
verseText: In the same way we also, when we were children, were enslaved to the elementary principles of the world.

text: When did God send forth His Son?
options: When the fullness of time had come
verseText: But when the fullness of time had come, God sent forth his Son, born of woman, born under the law,

text: Why was Jesus 'born under the law'?
options: To redeem those who were under the law
To show how impossible it was
verseText: to redeem those who were under the law, so that we might receive adoption as sons.

text: Because believers are sons, what has God sent into their hearts?
options: The Spirit of his Son, crying, 'Abba! Father!'
verseText: And because you are sons, God has sent the Spirit of his Son into our hearts, crying, “Abba! Father!”

text: Paul expresses concern that the Galatians were turning back to observing what?
options: Days and months and seasons and years (likely Jewish festivals)
verseText: You observe days and months and seasons and years!

text: In the Hagar/Sarah allegory, Hagar represents which covenant and location?
options: The covenant from Mount Sinai / Present Jerusalem
verseText: Now this may be interpreted allegorically: these women are two covenants. One is from Mount Sinai, bearing children for slavery; she is Hagar. Now Hagar is Mount Sinai in Arabia; she corresponds to the present Jerusalem, for she is in slavery with her children.

text: In the Hagar/Sarah allegory, Sarah represents which covenant and reality?
options: The promise / The Jerusalem above (which is free)
verseText: But the Jerusalem above is free, and she is our mother... Now you, brothers, like Isaac, are children of promise.

text: What warning does Paul give about accepting circumcision (as necessary for salvation)?
options: Christ will be of no advantage, and one is obligated to keep the whole law
It is recommended but not required
verseText: Look: I, Paul, say to you that if you accept circumcision, Christ will be of no advantage to you. I testify again to every man who accepts circumcision that he is obligated to keep the whole law.

text: Through the Spirit, by faith, what do believers eagerly wait for?
verseText: For through the Spirit, by faith, we ourselves eagerly wait for the hope of righteousness.

text: In Christ Jesus, what counts for anything?
verseText: For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision nor uncircumcision counts for anything, but only faith working through love.

text: Christian freedom should not be used as an opportunity for what?
verseText: For you were called to freedom, brothers. Only do not use your freedom as an opportunity for the flesh, but through love serve one another.

text: How can believers avoid gratifying the desires of the flesh?
verseText: But I say, walk by the Spirit, and you will not gratify the desires of the flesh.

text: What is the relationship between the desires of the flesh and the desires of the Spirit?
options: They are opposed to each other
The Spirit eliminates fleshly desires immediately
verseText: For the desires of the flesh are against the Spirit, and the desires of the Spirit are against the flesh, for these are opposed to each other, to keep you from doing the things you want to do.

text: Which of these is listed as a 'work of the flesh'?
verseText: Now the works of the flesh are evident: sexual immorality, impurity, sensuality, idolatry, sorcery, enmity, strife, jealousy, fits of anger, rivalries, dissensions, divisions, envy, drunkenness, orgies, and things like these.

text: Which of these is listed as part of the 'fruit of the Spirit'?
verseText: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control...

text: What have those who belong to Christ Jesus done?
options: Crucified the flesh with its passions and desires
verseText: And those who belong to Christ Jesus have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.

text: If believers live by the Spirit, what else should they do?
options: Keep in step with the Spirit
verseText: If we live by the Spirit, let us also keep in step with the Spirit.

text: How should believers restore someone caught in a transgression?
verseText: Brothers, if anyone is caught in any transgression, you who are spiritual should restore him in a spirit of gentleness. Keep watch on yourself, lest you too be tempted.

text: What command fulfills the 'law of Christ'?
verseText: Bear one another's burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ.

text: What should each person test?
verseText: But let each one test his own work, and then his reason to boast will be in himself alone and not in his neighbor.

text: What responsibility does each person have?
options: To bear the burdens of the weak
verseText: For each will have to bear his own load.

text: What should the one who is taught the word share with the one who teaches?
verseText: Let the one who is taught the word share all good things with the one who teaches.

text: Sowing to the flesh will reap what?
verseText: For the one who sows to his own flesh will from the flesh reap corruption...

text: Sowing to the Spirit will reap what?
verseText: ...but the one who sows to the Spirit will from the Spirit reap eternal life.

text: What encouragement does Paul give regarding doing good?
options: Do good only when it's easy
Let us not grow weary of doing good, for in due season we will reap
Expect immediate rewards for doing good
Do good only to those who do good to you
verseText: And let us not grow weary of doing good, for in due season we will reap, if we do not give up.

text: To whom should believers especially do good?
options: Especially to those who are of the household of faith
verseText: So then, as we have opportunity, let us do good to everyone, and especially to those who are of the household of faith.

text: What does Paul emphasize by mentioning he is writing the final section 'with large letters'?
options: The standard practice of the time
verseText: See with what large letters I am writing to you with my own hand.

text: What is the motivation of those forcing circumcision on the Galatians?
options: To make a good showing in the flesh and avoid persecution for the cross
verseText: It is those who want to make a good showing in the flesh who would force you to be circumcised, and only in order that they may not be persecuted for the cross of Christ.

text: What is the only thing Paul will boast in?
options: The cross of our Lord Jesus Christ
verseText: But far be it from me to boast except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by which the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world.

text: What truly counts, instead of circumcision or uncircumcision?
verseText: For neither circumcision counts for anything, nor uncircumcision, but a new creation.

text: What marks does Paul bear on his body?
verseText: From now on let no one cause me trouble, for I bear on my body the marks of Jesus.
